title: Day 1:Descriptive Stats and Visualizations
text:
May 22 9-1:30
Welcome
Introduction<- Put Eric’s intro here.
Descriptive Statistics

Activity with Descriptive Statistics and births14

Break?
Histograms and Boxplots
This is a discussion on graphing numeric variables in R

Activity with Boxplots and births14

Break
[Bar graphs and Mosaic Plots] <- Put Eric’s work here

This is a discussion of categorical variables in R

Lunch

Two numeric variables


Optional Homework

Check out the mosaic cheat sheet in the resources tab.
Try to install R on your personal computer, see notes here under If you like a challenge.

title: Descriptive statistics
text:
Load the libraries
library(openintro)

This is where the data lives

library(mosaic)

This is where our statistical functions live (most of them)

title: Descriptive statistics
text:
Explore the data frame
Try the following in the console.


View(x = county) 1
names(county)
dim(county)
?county


The View() function is capitalized in mosaic but lower case when using just the tidyverse.

title: Descriptive statistics
text:
The ? operator
The ? will bring up the help tab.
Try


?county
?mosaic
?mean()

title: Descriptive statistics
text:
Measures of center


mean()

mean(~pop2017,data=county, na.rm=TRUE)

median()

Find the median population from 2017

mode()

title: Descriptive statistics
text:
Measures of Spread


IQR(~pop2017,data=county, na.rm=TRUE)
sd()

title: Descriptive statistics
text:
All summary stats()


fivenum()
favstats(~pop2017,data=county, na.rm=TRUE)1
quartile()


favstats() is the friendliest and the one we use the most

title: Descriptive statistics
section: Get specific details on each state
text:
Get specific details on each state
Find the mean population for all 50 states.
mean(pop2017~state,data=county)

title: Descriptive statistics
text:
Activity
Open a new blank .rmd file

Paste this text into it.

title: Histograms and Boxplots
text:
Histograms and Boxplots
Let’s consider the county data frame.

county

# A tibble: 3,142 × 15
   name    state pop2000 pop2010 pop2017 pop_c…¹ poverty homeo…² multi…³ unemp…⁴
   <chr>   <fct>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <int>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>
 1 Autaug… Alab…   43671   54571   55504    1.48    13.7    77.5     7.2    3.86
 2 Baldwi… Alab…  140415  182265  212628    9.19    11.8    76.7    22.6    3.99
 3 Barbou… Alab…   29038   27457   25270   -6.22    27.2    68      11.1    5.9 
 4 Bibb C… Alab…   20826   22915   22668    0.73    15.2    82.9     6.6    4.39
 5 Blount… Alab…   51024   57322   58013    0.68    15.6    82       3.7    4.02
 6 Bulloc… Alab…   11714   10914   10309   -2.28    28.5    76.9     9.9    4.93
 7 Butler… Alab…   21399   20947   19825   -2.69    24.4    69      13.7    5.49
 8 Calhou… Alab…  112249  118572  114728   -1.51    18.6    70.7    14.3    4.93
 9 Chambe… Alab…   36583   34215   33713   -1.2     18.8    71.4     8.7    4.08
10 Cherok… Alab…   23988   25989   25857   -0.6     16.1    77.5     4.3    4.05
# … with 3,132 more rows, 5 more variables: metro <fct>, median_edu <fct>,
#   per_capita_income <dbl>, median_hh_income <int>, smoking_ban <fct>, and
#   abbreviated variable names ¹​pop_change, ²​homeownership, ³​multi_unit,
#   ⁴​unemployment_rate

title: Histograms and Boxplots
text:
A simple histogram
Map the unemployment rate for the counties in the US in 2019.

gf_histogram(~unemployment_rate,data = county)

title: Histograms and Boxplots
text:
Function arguments
Every function in R can take a lot of arguments. Let’s type ?gf_histogram to see the arguments for that function.



object = NULL,
binwidth,
linetype,
subtitle,


gformula = NULL,
alpha = 0.5,
size,
caption,


data = NULL,
color,
xlab,
geom = “bar”,


…,
fill,
ylab,
stat = “bin”,


bins = 25,
group,
title,
position = “stack”,

title: Histograms and Boxplots
text:
What do these do?
Start with the single variable histogram: gf_histogram(~unemployment_rate,data = county,...)


Edit the bins or binwidth, which get priority?
Edit colors and fill. Which tints what? (Hint colors are strings, use quotes) Here’s a list of colors
Add a title and caption. Remove the label from the x-axis add a good one to the y.
What the heck do size, linetype and group do?

title: Histograms and Boxplots
section: Here’s a graph that I made
text:
Here’s a graph that I made

gf_histogram(~unemployment_rate,data=county,bins=10, color="black",fill="purple", xlab="",ylab="Number of unemployed", title="US Umeployment by county", caption="Data is as of 2019",linetype = 5,size=2)

title: Histograms and Boxplots
text:
Show two variables
The histogram is a single variable graph by we can break up the data by grouping it.

#Take position ="dodge" out
gf_histogram(~unemployment_rate,data=county,bins=10, fill = ~metro)

title: Histograms and Boxplots
text:
Two variables (faceted):
Let’s make two histograms side by side.

gf_histogram(~unemployment_rate|~metro,data = county)





gf_boxplot(~unemployment_rate,data=county, color = ~metro)



# or 
gf_boxplot(unemployment_rate~metro,data=county)

title: Histograms and Boxplots
text:
Activity:
Open a new .rmd file and copy and paste this code into it.

title: Activity_Boxplot
text:
This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
When you click the Knit button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)

     speed           dist       
 Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
 1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
 Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
 Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
 3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
 Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00

title: Activity_Boxplot
text:
Including Plots
You can also embed plots, for example:





Note that the echo = FALSE parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.

title: To dos
text:
A sweater for the AC
A working laptop with an up to date browser on it (preferably with firefox or chrome.)
Lunch or money for the cafeteria.

We’ll try to get our hands on some snacks.

title: To dos
section: If you can have 5 minutes before hand:
text:
If you can have 5 minutes before hand:
Log onto the RStudio server

HCC Faculty:
Log onto the HCC Rstudio server.
HCC faculty your username is your hcc email with the @hcc.edu.
Nic’s is nschwab@hcc.edu
Your password is your hcc email password.


WSU and STCC faculty:
We are working on getting you temporary usernames and passwords for HCC Rstudio Server. Hopefully you’ll get an email from Nic with usernames by Sunday the 21.

title: To dos
text:
If you like a challenge:
Install R and R Studio then type the following into the console:
install.packages("mosaic")
install.packages("tidyverse")
install.packages("openintro")
note: its not that hard, but you may experience errors that the rest of the group does get, we’ll help you with those.
